Authors: Dhanushka Nadeeshan Wanasinghe, Peter E Mortimer
Title:
Taxonomic and phylogenetic insights into novel Ascomycota
from forest woody litter
Keywords:
Asexual morph; Greater Mekong Subregion; Pleosporales;
sexual morph; Yunnan
Abstract:
While surveying the mycobiomes of dead woody litter in
Yunnan Province, China, numerous isolates with affinity to Pleosporales
(Dothideomycetes, Ascomycota) were recovered. The present work
characterizes the mycobiota associated with dead woody twigs found in
terrestrial habitats in the Kunming area of Yunnan. Of additional
interest is that the samples discussed in this man-uscript were all
collected by the 5-year-old son of one of the authors. The taxonomic
novelties were recognized based on morphological comparisons coupled
with phylogenetic analyses of multiple gene sequences (non-translated
loci and protein-coding regions). Neokalmusia jonahhulmei sp. nov. is
introduced in Didymosphaeriaceae (Pleosporales) as a woody-based
saprobic ascomycete that pos-sesses multiloculate ascostromata immersed
under a black clypeus-like structure, subglobose to ampulliform locules,
an ascostromatal wall with thin-walled cells of textura angularis,
cylindrical to clavate, short pedicellate asci with furcate ends, and
3-septate, brown, fusiform, guttulate as-cospores. Thyridaria
jonahhulmei (Thyridariaceae) is introduced with sexual and asexual
(coelomy-cetous) features. The sexual morph is characterized by globose
to subglobose, ostiolate ascomata, a pruinose layer of yellow to reddish
or orange-brown material forming around the apices of the ostiolar
necks, a peridium with textura angularis cells, cylindrical to
cylindric-clavate asci with a long pedicel and an ocular chamber, brown,
ellipsoid to fusoid, 2Â–3-septate, euseptate, rough-walled guttulate
ascospores, and the asexual morph is featured by pycnidial conidiomata,
phialidic, ampulliform to doliiform, hyaline, flexuous and smooth
conidiogenous cells, brown, guttulate, ellipsoidal and aseptate
conidia.
